results.title: A Pocketful of Rye
results.creator_credit: Guy Slater, George Gallaccio and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.
In this sinister tale, set in the 1940’s, Miss Marple sets about unravelling the mysterious murder of city financier, Rex Fortesque. When the cause of death is identified as poisoning, suspicion falls on the occupants of the family home, Yew Tree Lodge. But the police are perplexed as the only clue to the murder is a handful of rye in the dead man’s pocket. However, when another murder shortens the life of suspects, the connection with the nursery rhyme “Sing a Song of Sixpence” is all too clear to Miss Marple.

results.title: Under southern skies
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description: A series in which Dr. Sue Hanckel seeks out remarkable individuals who raise critical issues about the environment. An exciting and visual set of programs with broad appeal by the internationally acclaimed cinematographer and director, Michael Edols.

results.title: Embracing the Future
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Historian and environmentalist Dr. Jonathon King points to an optimistic future, citing that humans are rational beings with the capacity to change and ensure a sustainable future. Phillip Toyne, Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, demonstrates viable ways of reversing much of the damage done to our soil. Presenter Sue Hanckel concludes that “…we owe it to ourselves and our children to embrace the future with a vision that is life-affirming and positive.”

results.title: Fossil Fuels: Heading Towards 2010
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Continued life on this planet is dependent on our ability to maintain a balance with our biosphere and our resources. In the pursuit of a sustainable world, humans need to examine their direction on behalf of all living species. Sue Hanckel examines the paradox of a world which is trying to feed its billions and develop economically yet at the same time create a sustainable future for the generations to come. Particular attention is paid to our over dependence on fossil fuels and ways in which alternative forms of energy can be developed.

results.title: Extinction is forever
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Under southern skies”.
This episode looks at various species that are endangered in Australia. Doctor Tony Oliver of the West Australian Department of Agriculture discusses the complex and fragile interdependence of Australia’s plant kingdom and animals.

results.title: Forest for the Trees
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Within 30 years, at the present rate of logging, all available old forests will have been felled for timber. This program takes us to Eden on the south coast of N.S.W and Pemberton in W.A in an effort to understand how we can balance our commercial need for a timber industry with our vital need to conserve and protect the environment. Presented by Ruth Hanckel.

results.title: Appropriate Harvesting
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Under southern skies”.
The critical issue for the next century is how to sustain the productivity of agricultural land without contributing to any further environmental chaos. Sue Henckel investigates 3 different approaches to appropriate farming; a small flower company which harvests wildflowers, a vineyard in the Barossa Valley and a small tropical farm in far north Queensland.

results.title: Floral tapestry
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Host Sue Henckel rekindles her passion for wildflowers while touring through two parks. She also visits artist and philosopher William Ricketts whose sculptures in the 1930’s expressed his understanding of his First Nation peoples subjects relationship to their environments. She also meets the descendants of the artist’s subjects who as commercial artists in the 90’s continue to express their relationship to the landscape and plant life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media

results.title: Healing is believing
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Under southern skies”.
In this episode, host Sue Henckel travels to the Gulf of Carpentaria where her guide Thancoupie, an aboriginal healer, takes her on a practical excursion revealing her traditional knowledge of plants that have been used for centuries for their medicinal properties. Thancoupie collects a variety of plants and prepares them to treat ailments such as diarrhoea, colds and tropical ulcers. She also reveals methods used by her ancestors to control their birth-rate discussing the consequences of large families in nomadic tribes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media

results.title: Custodians of the bush
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Sue Henckel travels to far north Queensland to meet Thancoupie, an Aboriginal healer, who explains the ancient tradition of holistic medicine that nurtures, heals and protects. Thancoupie provides an education on the qualities and properties of Australian native flora, showing that it is the hunter gatherers who have provided the rich source of essential substances used in modern medicines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
